Award.AwardTitle: New Directions in Reverse Mathematics and Applied Computability Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematics today benefits from having "firm foundations", by which we usually mean a system of axioms sufficient to prove the various theorems we care about. But given a particular theorem, can we specify precisely which axioms are needed to derive it? This is a natural question, and also an ancient one: over 2000 years ago, the Greek mathematicians were asking it about Euclid's geometry. Reverse mathematics is an area of mathematical logic that offers a modern approach to this kind of question, by classifying mathematical theorems according to their logical strength. This offers a deeper insight into the fundamental ideas and methods needed to prove a given theorem. More precisely, reverse mathematics provides a framework in which to compare and contrast results from disparate areas of mathematics, which helps elucidate the underpinnings of various branches of the mathematical sciences, and thereby leads to a better understanding of mathematics and its applications.

A striking fact repeatedly demonstrated in this area is that the vast majority of mathematical propositions can be classified into one of a small number of categories. But for some very important and fundamental theorems this is not the case. Dzhafarov's research focuses on theorems of this ?irregular" type, including Ramsey's theorem, various equivalents of the axiom of choice, and principles arising from certain problems in cognitive science. In this project, Dzhafarov will work to achieve a greater understanding of the complexities of these "irregular" theorems, to find new examples of such theorems from previously unexplored areas of mathematics, and to apply the reverse mathematics analysis to questions from outside of mathematics. This will be facilitated by the application of methods from computability theory and proof theory, and by the addition of ideas from various collaborations across a number of areas of pure and applied mathematics, as well as interactions with members of the multidisciplinary University of Connecticut logic group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Everyone knows that some math problems are harder to solve than others. But a problem can be hard to solve for different reasons. In some cases, it is because we do not yet sufficiently understand the problem, and our methods for solving it are unrefined and hence complicated. As we study it further, and encounter more examples and applications of it, our methods improve, and solving the problem becomes easier. (At a high level, this is a characteristic of solving any kind of problem, mathematical or otherwise.) On the other hand, some problems seem inherently difficult no matter how much time we spend with them. When a simplification is impossible, it is natural to want to know this outright, so as not to spend too much time looking for one. For example, such knowledge can tell us if a particular computer program can be made to run significantly faster, or to use fewer CPU resources. More generally, it translates to knowing that a given mathematical problem cannot be solved by elementary methods, or by using the same techniques as another.


The project concerned a prominent approach for systematically measuring the complexity of mathematical problems, called "reverse mathematics". The basic idea here is to work in the opposite direction that mathematicians typically do: that is, instead of starting with a fixed set of basic truths (called axioms), and trying to derive all other mathematical theorems (or results) from them, here we start with a mathematical theorem and try to figure out the precise axioms needed to prove it. There is a deep and well-studied relationship between this approach and the act of trying to solve mathematical problems, linking the concept of mathematical proof with problem-solving and computation. In practice, we use several commonly-encountered sets of axioms, and try to determine which of these precisely "captures" a particular mathematical theorem. This means that for a given mathematical result, we first look for the simplest set of axioms in which the theorem can be proved. Then, separately, we try to derive each of the axioms from our theorem, effectively proving that the theorem "requires" precisely these axioms to prove. This naturally leads to the concept of the "strength" of a mathematical theorem---intuitively, how hard the theorem is to prove. A theorem requiring more complex axioms in the above sense can be regarded as having greater strength than a theorem requiring simpler axioms. And, by extension, two theorems requiring the same set of axioms can be regarded as having the same strength.


A remarkable empirical fact, repeatedly demonstrated in the literature, is that when theorems of ordinary mathematics are analyzed in the above sense, many of them end up having the same strength, and in fact, this analysis gives rise to just five basic groups of distinct strengths. Far from suggesting that there are only five theorems in all of mathematics, it does nonetheless suggest that in a very broad sense, there are five basic categories of logical reasoning that show up repeatedly in mathematical proofs, spanning all areas of the mathematical sciences. This suggests a great deal of regularity underlying much of mathematical practice. Nonetheless, there are many notable exceptions to the above phenomenon. These are mathematical theorems which can be shown to fall outside the main five categories described above, and whose strength is therefore much more difficult to understand. These include important theorems from combinatorics, model theory, set theory, and other areas. Over the past decade, the investigation of these outlier theorems has spawned a highly active industry of research.


This project has played a major role in this endeavor, and has contributed some of its most significant recent breakthroughs, including over a dozen research publications authored and co-authored by the principal investigator. In the past five years alone, there have been eight international conferences dedicated to the topics with which the project is concerned, either organized by the PI, or featuring him as an invited speaker. Among the highlights of the work at hand are solutions to several longstanding open problems, and major progressions towards the resolution of others. These include some of the most challenging and significant open problems in the subject, but also a large number of new ones. Additionally, the PI, under this project, has led a campaign to enhance collaborations and interactions between different areas, most notably between computability theory and computable analysis. The latter collaboration has been especially fruitful, effectively creating a new combined research discipline, with a high level of activity and enthusiasm. Throughout, the PI has worked to involve as participants in the research activities and associated meetings, students and other young researchers. The enterprise of studying the strength of mathematical theorems remains a highly active one, and promises to be a rich longterm source of problems and results.
